name: Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP)
summary: A specialized form of cognitive-behavioral therapy that involves systematic exposure to anxiety-provoking thoughts or situations while preventing the compulsive responses that usually follow.
description: Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is a frontline, evidence-based treatment primarily for Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). It involves gradually and systematically exposing individuals to feared thoughts, images, or situations that trigger anxiety, while guiding them to refrain from performing compulsive behaviors or rituals. Over time, this reduces the distress associated with obsessive triggers and helps break the cycle of obsessions and compulsions. ERP can be delivered in individual therapy, group therapy, or intensive outpatient programs, and is considered one of the most effective interventions for OCD.

clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and effective, though it can produce significant short-term anxiety during exposures.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Decades of clinical trials confirm ERP’s efficacy in reducing OCD symptoms, with effect sizes comparable or superior to medication in many cases.

sections.text: ERP is based on the principle of habituation and inhibitory learning. By repeatedly confronting feared stimuli without performing compulsions, individuals learn that anxiety diminishes on its own and that feared outcomes are unlikely. Over time, this weakens the association between obsessive thoughts and compulsive rituals, reducing symptom severity.

sections.preparation: Assessment of obsessions, compulsions, and avoidance behaviors; development of a fear hierarchy.
procedure: Gradual exposure to feared thoughts, images, or situations (imaginal and/or in vivo).
Therapist support, modeling, and reinforcement of non-ritualizing behavior.
sections.frequency: Typically weekly sessions; intensive programs may meet multiple times per week.
sections.duration: 12–20 sessions for standard course, though severe OCD may require longer.

sections.treatment_phase: Engage in structured exposure tasks while preventing rituals.
sections.post_session: Process experience, assign new exposures, reinforce learning.

uncommon: Dropout due to difficulty tolerating exposures
rare: Exacerbation of symptoms if not properly supported

relative: Lack of engagement or support system

ideal_candidates: Individuals with OCD willing to confront feared thoughts and situations
Clients with access to therapist support or strong support systems
screening_required: Assessment scales (e.g., Yale-Brown Obsessive-Compulsive Scale, Y-BOCS)

practitioner: Licensed therapists trained in ERP or CBT for OCD
facility: Private practice, outpatient clinics, intensive treatment programs

studies: Foa EB, Kozak MJ. (1986). Emotional processing of fear: exposure to corrective information.
Simpson HB, et al. (2008). Randomized controlled trial of ERP vs risperidone augmentation for refractory OCD.
sections.limitations: Some patients refuse or drop out due to difficulty tolerating exposure-related anxiety.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Varies based on session length and frequency (commonly $2,000–$5,000 per course)
sections.cost_effectiveness: High—often prevents need for long-term medication or hospitalization

concurrent_therapies: CBT for co-occurring depression or anxiety
Family therapy for support and accommodation reduction

sections.children: ERP adapted with parental involvement, shorter sessions, and developmentally appropriate exposures.
sections.autism: Modified ERP may be beneficial but requires tailoring to cognitive profile.

items: Considered the gold standard for OCD.
Requires high therapist expertise and patient motivation.
Exposure tasks must be collaboratively tailored to patient’s hierarchy.

seo.title: Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) Therapy for OCD
seo.description: Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the gold-standard therapy for OCD, helping individuals confront fears while resisting compulsions to reduce symptoms and improve functioning.
